info.document:
Skylar Stearley (from left), Miriya Pinkerman and Emalyn Kruse listen during an Advanced Placement art history course.

Welcome, Venus de Milo, to the walls of Southeast High School.

You, famous Greek sculpture that you are, will not actually make an appearance until next week, but the students in Greg Spangler's classroom on Friday sketched images of the compatriots from your time: the friezes and sculptures and architectural wonders of the Parthenon and Acropolis.

The art and architecture of ancient Greece comes to Southeast via the first Advanced Placement art history class in Lincoln Public Schools.

It is one of six AP art history courses taught across the state, and one of just a few art history courses offered at LPS.

Students who take the AP exam can earn college credit.

Spangler had wanted to teach art history to high school students before he got his official Southeast ID three years ago.

"I'd spent so long studying it and have always had a great passion for it," he said. "I think it was one of the first questions I asked (the Southeast principal) about."

Spangler earned undergraduate degrees in art and English and a master's degree in art history before he decided he wanted to teach.

Not long after, he began working with administrators on the training, certification and approval needed to teach it.

"It's a passion because it synthesizes so many disciplines so well -- religion, history, arts, economics. It so beautifully combines all that with the visual," he said. "For me, it was a beautiful entrance into the world of history."

Students in the class must memorize 250 images, and Spangler has them sketch images of the art on flashcards, along with notes on the form, function, content and context of each work.

The district offers about 25 AP courses in subjects such as English, economics, science and world language, said district curriculum director Takako Olson.

The art history class is similar to the survey courses offered in college, Spangler said, and that struck a cord with me.

As a college freshman, a dear friend and I signed up for those and loved them. As it turns out, my friend made art history her life's work. I didn't, but I've loved art since, and those old, dusty art history textbooks are still on my bookshelves.

Maybe one of those students will be similarly inspired. Here's my tip: The Venus de Milo is the one with no arms.

Coming full circle

Sixteen years ago on Sept. 11, Jake Bogus walked into his eighth-grade U.S. history class in Minden and learned terrorists had flown planes into the World Trade Center.

His favorite teacher was staring at the television screen.

"He said, 'Today in class we're just going to watch the news because our country has been attacked. This is going to be in your history books someday,'" Bogus recalled.

Fast forward to Sept. 11, 2017, and Bogus has his own eighth-grade U.S. history class at Schoo Middle School, and is taking time on the anniversary of the attacks to teach about them.

"It's one of the very few things my students can ask me about and I can remember it firsthand: where I was and how I felt," he said.

They discuss what happened -- none of those students were alive then -- and Bogus talks to them about "flashbulb memories," those events so significant people remember in detail what they were doing when they found out.

Like walking into your eighth-grade U.S. history class with no earthly idea you'd be talking to your own eighth-grade history class about it one day.

Being prepared Sign up for our daily news email

The top headlines from JournalStar.com. Delivered at 11 a.m. Monday-Friday.

Sign Up! Daily Headlines

Top headlines from journalstar.com. Delivered at 11 a.m. Monday-Friday.

Obituaries I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site consitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.

On Friday, fourth- and fifth-graders at Randolph Elementary took an unusual field trip.

They walked from their school to a nearby church, took a bus to Southwest High School, got situated on the floor of the high school gym and watched "Wreck it Ralph."

The students were playing a minor part in a bigger production: practicing how their school district would react if something horrible happened.

LPS officials staged a mock "reunification" drill -- practicing getting students from their school to a new location and connecting parents with their kids.

School shootings have made such procedures necessary, though they could be used any time kids must be evacuated from school and can't go back -- a gas leak, for instance.

LPS Security Director Joe Wright said reunifying parents with their children is one of the toughest jobs schools face in such scenarios.

"This procedure is a compilation of (advice) from a lot of people who have had to go through this before," he said.

LPS's drill walked staff through the steps, which are part of a broader set of security procedures followed by schools.

Jolene Palmer, director of security for the state Department of Education, said LPS is one of the first districts to put the reunification plans into place.

LPS officials have designated Southwest as the reunification site for all elementary and middle schools. Officials have identified temporary sites -- such as a church -- near each school where students would go to wait for buses to take them to Southwest.

Once there, students would stay in the gym, where movies, games and toys are stored nearby and available to keep them occupied. Parents would be directed to an area where LPS officials could verify their relationship to the student. Nurses, social workers, psychologists and interpreters would be on hand to help.

Staff would return kids to their parents in a separate hallway, and a private area is designated where parents would be told if their child had been injured.

The idea, LPS officials said, is to create a controlled environment to keep everyone calm, give parents privacy if there's bad news and make sure LPS safely reunites parents with their families.
